comment.narrative: Activity Results 1: 1.1.UNDP has provided support in implementing the National Action Plan on Gender Equality (2015-2017) – the part related to output 3.1.2.1. “To generalize the judicial practice on crimes against women and girls during the period of 2011-2014 (articles 129, 130, 132, 133, 144, 153, 154, 155 of the Criminal Code) and to make recommendations for the proper and uniform application of the rules by the courts. Develop a document on training of judges of all district, inter-district and regional courts based on recommendations for correct and uniform application by the courts of law on crimes against women and girls”. 1.2. Support provided on implementation the National Action Plan on UN SC Resolution #1325. Gender experts developed methodology and training programme on UNSCR 1325 “Women, Peace and Security” in order to build capacities for law enforcement agencies of KR in September 2016. The training itself was facilitated to representatives of Military Institute of Law Enforcement, as well as resource materials for curriculum introduced. The resource book for Law Enforcement agencies was disseminated 1.3. UNDP contributed to building capacity of national partners on implementation of international and national gender equality commitments: the Head of Gender Policy Department of the Ministry of labour and social development was supported for participation the International forum «Reconsidering Gender Equality and Peaceful Societies» (Bangkok, May 7-8, 2016); MP Altybaeva for participation in 60th session of CSW in NY; 1.4. Several Gender and Leadership schools for women MPs and women-candidates were conducted; 1.5. Technical support in advocating for several draft laws initiated by women MPs were provided, one on registration of early religious marriages is signed by the President, the domestic violence law is due for the second hearings, gender quotas in local elections is due for the second hearings). 1.6. Within the framework of SGBV internati

Output 1: 1. # of conflict prevention-related laws/ strategies/ plans/ policies drafted, amended, passed or implemented (# of which promote gender equality). 2.1.# of stakeholders trained and capable to apply MPR-D methodology. 2.2. # of scenario cases developed and discussed. 3. # of dialogue platforms conducted and # of preventivemeasures/ actions taken following these platforms (# of measures that promote gender equality issues and increasing the role of women in peacebuilding). 4. # of mediation and dialogue pilots implemented and documented.
Output 2: 1. # of local NGOs, advisory committees, women and youth organizations able to monitor and respond to potential conflict escalation (# of women leaders in the trainings and # of preventive actions undertaken by women. 2. # of capacity building interventions conducted for Advisory Committees that have led to concrete positive changes in their work (# of interventions with tangible benefit for the role of women in peacebuilding). 3. # of new collaborations/ initiatives kick-started in the area of conflict monitoring and preventive action based on networking efforts. 4. # of documented cases in which ICT for conflict prevention was used in the context of monitoring and preventive action. 5. # of women initiatives contributing to confidence- and peacebuilding.
Output 3: 1. # of recommendations of risk assessment accepted by border security and considered for future planning. 2. # of consultations/ negotiations supported towards reaching agreement on possible cross-border cooperation between Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: 1. National Institutions have limited capacities to design and implement conflict prevention policies. Governmental officials were not aware on conflict sensitivity, gender aspects, and had no enough skills to develop policy. 2. Government doesn’t use methodology to manage political risks for development. 3. Prior to International Conference on conflict sensitive law-making there was no dialogue between civil society and authorities. There is lack of collaboration between Oblast-level officials and civil society on one side and state decisions makers on the other to jointly monitor tensions and take early preventive action (including mediation). 4. Lack of support to mentor and coach real mediation processes or mediation practice support.
Output 2: 1. Local NGOs, advisory committees, women and youth organizations have limited ability to monitor and respond to potential conflict escalation. 2. Advisory Committees have limited capacities to initiate conflict prevention and peace building interventions. 3. Local NGOs, advisory committees, women and youth organizations do not sufficiently coordinate their efforts. 4. ICT review has identified lack of support for ICT development in peace building. 5.Lack of support to women driven initiatives in peace building.
Output 3: 1. Limited capacities to assess potential conflict risks related to border security. 2. Lack of cross border cooperation between Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan.

comment.narrative: - Recognized and formalized mechanism of cooperation of stakeholders on RoL for implementation issues; - Training program and methodology on capacity building of key RoL institutions as part of the judicial reform implementation is developed - Methodology on financial assessments of Judicial Laws finalized - Built national capacity for donor coordination - At least ten CSOs are engaged in the Judicial reform process and their capacity is enhanced - Establishment of mechanism for civil society engagement in Rule of Law implementation reform process. - Establishment of a working group for the development of a concept plan on long term judicial reform

- The mechanisms for cooperation was established with support of donor community. The coordination council and its Secretariat is functioning and meeting on constant basis. - At least 2 training programms have been developed in cooperation with Government Office - The methodology on financial assessment is finalized and handed over to legal department of Government Office - National capacity to coordinate activities of the development partners is build via communication platforms - At least 20 CSOs are engaged and successfully monitoring the rule of law reform - The adequate mechanism to coordinate the CSO network is established by UNDP - The working group supported via national expert on development of strategic documents

- Recognized and formalized mechanism of cooperation of stakeholders on RoL for implementation issues; - Level of knowledge by consultative body members and relevant state officials on international principles and standards on cooperation in rule of Law matters increased. - Training program and methodology on capacity building of key RoL institutions as part of the judicial reform implementation is developed - At least ten CSOs are engaged in the Judicial reform process and their capacity is enhanced - Establishment of mechanism for civil society engagement in Rule of Law implementation reform process. - Establishment of a working group for the development of a concept plan on long term judicial reform

- The mechanisms for cooperation was established with support of donor community. description.narrative: Improving the coverage and management effectiveness of Protected Areas in the Central Tian Shan Mountains.
independent political entity

comment.narrative:
1.1.1. The Nature State Park "Khan-Teniri" has been established on 275 800,3 ha by the Decree of the Kyrgyz Republic dated February 12, 2016 #62. Atlas of the Flora and Fauna of the Protected Areas in the Central Tian-Shan has been published to raise awareness of the wide range audience on biodiversity of the PAs in the Project site. Trail cameras have been set to identify migration routes of the large mammals established exteral borders of the ecologicl corridors; Based on obtained data the external borders of the ecological corridors have been identified; Borders of the ecological corridors and regimes in ecological corridors is being condisered by land owners and users.
1.2.3. No illigal hunting was detected in the territory of the Khan-Teniri Park during the raids of freelance inspectors (January-November 2016). The Supervisory Board for the Khan-Teniri Park was established as an advisory and supporting decision making body. Regulation on the Board was approved by local decision makers.
2.2.3. Multilateral agreements on collaboration among stakeholders and mainstreaming biodiversity in their developments plans (e.g., herding committees, private hunting companies, tour operators, self-local governance, Khan-Teniri State Nature Park) were signed in 2016. Memorandum of Understating has been signed among Department on Rational Use of Nature Resources, Department on Pasture and Department on Tourism for integration of the biodiversity in relevant policy and developments plans and collaboration in policy implementation. 2.4.3. The alternative livelihood programme has been implementing in target communities. Local communities are receiving micro capital grants for achieve biodiversity-friendly outcomes. The Project organized study tours for local decision makers, local communities and PAs staff to Chon-Kemin, Salkyn-Tor State Nature Parks to share experiences on PA management and local communities involvement in PA management. The Project organized capacity bui

description.narrative: To improve the coverage and effectiveness of protected areas in the Central Tian Shan Mountains so as to expand threatened species representation in the national system
Population size of snow leopard Uncia Uncia in Central Tian Shan shows an increasing trend

comment.narrative: Low numbers of snow leopard unable to quantify
By project end target area offers permanent habitat for 5 females with cubs

During field surveys conducted by the Biology and Soil Institute three sites in the Project area had signs of snow leopard activities A questionnaire among local herders indicated that about 57 snow leopards were seen in the area The snow leopard and its prey species habitat migration routes seasons directions were developed
According to the Global Snow Leopard and Ecosystem Protection Programme that aims to identify and secure 20 landscapes across snow leopard range by year 2020 there are 23 national scale landscapes Report of the FFICMS workshop Bishkek Kyrgyzstan 1st 2nd December 2014
The Project site has been included as one of the key landscapes for show leopard conservation in the Kyrgyz Republic

description.narrative: Territorial coverage of SPNAs in Central Tian Shan Mountains which provide habitat for the endangered snow leopard

comment.narrative: 1491179 ha Existing Sarychat Ertash reserve area
Up to 3361199 ha by project end

Researchers from Biology and Soil Institute of the National Academy of Sciences of the Kyrgyz Republic have conducted the field study in the Project site
Based on the results of the literature review and obtained data from field survey Biology and Soil Institute provided the following i Information on preliminary assessment of the flora vertebrates mammals birds coldblooded animals ii summary lists of flora and fauna locations biota large mammals migration routes iii Preliminary assessment of sacred natural sites and cultural landscapes of the Project site Soil types ivRecommendations for new establishing KhanTengri State Nature Park zoning and ecological corridors borders
Flora
10 vegetation types 457 plant species found and identified Out of which 5 species included in the Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic 8 endemic species which are natural to or characteristic to this place 11 species can be found only in the Project site in the Kyrgyz Republic In addition 4 mosses 122 mushrooms 287 lichen were found
Fauna
100 bird species out of which 8 species included in the Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic 4 species included in the Red List of the IUCN 13 species are listed in the CITES appendix II
22 mammals out of which 5 species included in the Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic 4 species included in the Red List of the IUCN 4 species are listed in the CITES appendix II I
Staff of the State Agency on Environment Protection and Forestry completed a feasibility study for establishing a new PA The socioeconomic impact of the new PA was identified including i socioeconomic status population growth and land use composition measures ii current use of the Project site land for agricultural and industry use and future prospect iii water and mineral resources and their longterm perspective iv modern use of forest and game species in the Project site and prospects v anthropogenic pressures and threats to landscape nature resources
Based on the results of the feasibility study and ecological assessment tentatively an area of 325785 ha for the new park was identified which has the potential to ensure conservation of mountain fragile ecosystems including flora and fauna along with sustainable development for local people residing around the Park Out of 325785 ha 2268882 ha were identified for the core zone of the Park 17808 ha ecological stabilization zone for restoration and conservation activities 83234 ha for tourism recreational zone 727655 ha zone for limited economic activities where traditional farming practices and biodiversity friendly activities are allowed A social survey was held among local people to be impacted by the park creation ie their lands will be transferred to Protected areas category The survey involved 1383 households of which 75 indicated support for the establishment of the park and 17 against its establishment

description.narrative: Habitat connectivity sustainability and effectiveness of PAs in Central Tian Shan are enhanced by regulating land use in buffer zones wildlife corridors and other intervening landscapes
Area over which territorial land use planning is fully aligned with requirements for regulated resource use stipulated in the management plans of PA buffer zones and corridors

comment.narrative: 0 ha

0 ha
Key land owners and users in the Project site were identified The new PA area would largely consist of the AkSuu rayon state land reserve 23687170 ha Otradnaya local selfgovernment body LSGB 237763 ha Teplklyuchenka LSGB 98345 ha KeregeTash LSGB 57683 ha BoryBash LSGB 20685 ha Oktyabr LSGB 17850 ha AkBulun LSGB 65326 ha Chelpek LSGB 46466 ha Karakol forestry 345015ha
Out of 325 785 ha 49399 ha are covered with forest 127443 ha occupied by pasture lands 9324 ha covered with water bodies 50 ha of roads 101646 ha of glaciers and 2054724 ha refer to the other land category rocks or stones etc
It is expected that out of 325785 ha 988968 ha of the KhanTengri Park territory will be included in its buffer zone where limited traditional economic activities for local communities are allowed
According to the legislation on land transfer of the Kyrgyz Republic the bottomup approach is used Nine key land owners LSGB agreed to the land transfer at local level At present PA establishment documents are being prepared for getting approval at regional and oblast levels
Taking into account recommendations of the National Academy of Science on establishment of ecological corridors to connect the new KhanTengri Park with the existing SarychatEertash Reserve ecological corridors for migratory mammals were mapped and land owners identified
Local governments local selfgovernment bodies and local communities have been informed about establishing ecological corridors and its regimes
The establishment of the ecological corridors will be accomplished after approval of amendments to the Law on PAs of the Kyrgyz Republic and Regulation on Ecological Corridors which is now under the consideration of the Kyrgyz Republic Parliament and then the Government
Guidelines on development of PA management Plan prepared by the Project were approved by the order of the SAEPF Director
Biodiversity conservation has been mainstreamed into the Sustainable Development Strategy of the IssykKul region for 20152017 and its Action Plan

description.narrative: Better management of hunting in buffers and corridors as reflected in percent of trophy hunting that is controlled and monitored

comment.narrative: Only 30 of trophy hunting is legal because hunters are uncontrolled and unmonitored
90 of trophy hunting is legally licensed

During the reporting period 100 of trophy hunting was controlled and monitored in the Project site
0 cases of violation by trophy hunters were recorded
A rangers handbook developed by the Project is under SAEPF approval After approval the handbook will be published and distributed to rangers and volunteer inspectors to improve their capacity in nature management

description.narrative: Increase in share of incomes of local communities from biodiversitycompatible alternative livelihood activities

comment.narrative: More than 60 of income comes from hunting
By project end at least 60 of income comes from sustainable livelihoods promoted by the project

No quantitative indicator is available at the moment
Project will be able to measure the quantitative indicator of change in share of incomes of local communities from biodiversity compatible livelihoods only in 2016
Social and economic assessment of target communities and development of Alternative Livelihood Programme has been completed

description.narrative: Law on SPNAs provides clear guidance on establishment management and responsible party for PA buffer zones and wildlife corridors

comment.narrative: Current law is unclear
Legislation improved through amendments by project end

No change of the baseline indicator
According to the Law on Protected Areas of the Kyrgyz Republic 2011 there are 4 zones in the state nature parks core zone ecological stabilization zone touristrecreational zone zone for limited economic activities
In accordance with SEAPF and Project board meeting suggestions November 2014 the above mentioned zones except for the core zone should be accepted as a buffer zone for the State Nature Park KhanTengri
During the reporting period the Project has reviewed the gaps in PA legislation and policy concerning establishment of zones its regimes and ecological corridors
The Project initiated review of the Law of the Kyrgyz Republic on PA By the Project support the following legislations were drafted The Regulation on PA establishment in the Kyrgyz Republic Regulation on Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic Regulation on land use in State Nature Parks Regulation on Ecological corridors and proposal for making amendments to Law on PA submitted to SAEPF for further endorsement These documents are under consideration of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic
In addition the Project provided technical support for development of a programme and action plans on transition to sustainable development of the ecological and economic system of IssykKul for 20152017 which was later integrated to the Sustainable Development Strategy of the IssykKul region for 20152017 and its Action Plan for the implementation of the Sustainable Development Strategy of the IssykKul region for 20152017 approved by order of the Plenipotentiary Representative of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic in IssykKul region dated February 9 2015 21 On approval of the Strategy for Sustainable Development of the IssykKul region for the years of 2015 2017
Biodiversity has been mainstreamed into the Sustainable Development Strategy of the IssykKul region for 20152017 and its Action Plan for respective years

description.narrative: Prosecution of illegal hunting in buffers and corridors

comment.narrative: Only 10 of incidents of illegal hunting successfully prosecuted
At least 50 of incidents of illegal hunting successfully prosecuted from Year 4 onwards

According to the Biosphere Territory IssykKul and volunteered inspectors the following data on prosecution of illegal hunting in the Project area have been obtained
i the first half of 2014 JanuaryJune 24 violations were registered out of which 17 illegal hunting 7 illegal logging of total collected penalty of 2500 USD
ii the first half of 2015 JanuaryJune 51 violations were registered of which 21 illegal hunting 15 illegal logging and 15 other cases of total penalty collected of 14255 USD
iii the second half of the 2014 JulyDecember 14 violations were registered of which 7 illegal hunting 5 illegal logging and 2 other cases of total penalty collected of 3399 USD
During the first half of 2015 51 violations were detected for a total amount 14255 USD first half of 2014 24 violations were detected for a total amount 2500 USD
Thus the detecting rate has been increased from 24 to 51 and the penalties amount from 2500 USD to 14255USD compared to the previous period
In total during this reporting period the second half of the 2014 and the first half of 2015 65 violations cases of the nature conservation legislations were recorded out of 28 cases on illegal hunting 20 cases on illegal logging and 17 other cases for carrying hunting weapons etc for the total penalty amount of 17654 USD
The Project enhanced the capacity of the Biosphere Territory IssykKel Karakol Nature State Park of SAEPF rangers and freelance inspectors through trainings workshops on involving local communities for awareness raising biodiversity conservation activities and conducting wildlife monitoring
The Project purchased and provided a group of volunteer inspectors with uniforms and equipment tent portable radio set GPS navigator binoculars etc for monitoring and conservation of wildlife and supported the antipoaching activities of Biosphere Territory IssykKel rangers
Department on Nature Resources Regulation passed the order in August 2014 to temporarily ban until 2016 game and sport hunting of all ungulate species in several regions of Kyrgyzstan including all districts of the IssykKul region

description.narrative: Reduced hunting effort directly attributable to changes in livelihoods among hunters

comment.narrative: 500 persons hunting in the area
150 reduced by 13 persons hunting by project end

No progress is reported at the moment in line with projects workplan
Development of the Alternative Livelihood Programme has been completed and the Programme implementation will cover local communities and people

HCF staff trained in composting and plastics recycling 2.3.3, 2.3.5 10 Bishkek hospitals supported in refurbishing/preparing waste storage locations and locations for technology installation 2.3.3, 2.3.5, 2.3.7 Non-incineration technologies and HCWM supplies procured and installed for all project HCFs (11 HCFs in Bishkek, 1 zone and 100 FAPs) 2.4.1 National training modules developed by Preventive Medicine as well as those used by the National Training Centre revised/improved and distributed among medical teaching institutions and schools. 3.1.1. National standards/guidelines on the management, storage and disposal of mercury containing products developed for large public and private entities, as well as HCFs. Order of MoH drafted prescribing a phased approach/total phase-out for the use of Hg-containing thermometers. Assessment of potential Cost-Recovery Mechanisms for the future disposal/treatment of Mercury containing products conducted. 3.2.1 Mercury management and phase-out plans developed and implemented for each project HCF. 500 medical personnel trained in the clean-up, storage and safe transport of Hg wastes. Transportation of infectious and anatomical waste exclusively assumed by authorized vehicle. 2.3.2 agreement with recycling companies for sending disinfection syringes reached for project HCFs in Bishkek. 2.3.3 Five (5) Bishkek hospitals supported in preparing waste storage locations in containers for non-incineration technology installation. Composting practices integrated in six (6) HCFs. 2.3.4 Non-incineration technologies and HCWM supplies procured and installed for 11 HCFs in Bishkek and 100 FAPs. 2.4.1 Training modules on HCWM designed and subsequently embedded in the curricula of the Medical Academy as well as the Medical Facility of the Kyrgyz-Russian-Slavik University and potentially a number of nursing schools. 3.1.1.National standards/guidelines on the management, storage and disposal of mercury containing products as well as action plan for phasing out mercury contacting product in healthcare sector refined according to state bodies comments in parallel with the obligatory law expertizes including the gender and sent for approval to the Government. Draft degree to transpose the

1.1.1 The working group has developed a draft National HCWM strategy, which includes all the categories of waste generated in the health sector (i.e. general waste, infectious waste, anatomical waste, pharmaceutical waste, chemical waste and radioactive waste) and which includes a National Action Plan and budget on HCWM for 2017-2020 according to the standards and degrees pertaining to HCWM. During the circulation of the National HCWM Strategy, National Action Plan and National HCWM Strategy Budget in order to obtain Government approval, the Ministry of Finance recommended a redrafting of all documents as per the Ministry of Health’s budget allocation. Therefore, documents were redrafted and discussed twice with members of an IWG. At present, the three documents approved by the Ministry of Health on 20 July, 2017 by its #649 Order. 1.2.1 The drafts of the following documents are being approved in December of 2017 by the Ministry of Health: 1) Standards on monitoring and evaluation of HCWM management practices; and 2) Job descriptions for personnel responsible for HCWM at healthcare facilities. Furthermore, the Scientific Production Association Preventive Medicine under the Ministry of Health (SPA Preventive Medicine) developed the first draft of the instruction on HCWM which includes all categories of waste generated in the health sector (i.e. general waste, infectious waste, anatomical waste, pharmaceutical waste, chemical waste and radioactive waste). Ultimately, this document will be approved at Governmental level. The draft of the standards on HCWM management in immunization offices was discussed in May 2017 with representatives of WHO and the Republican Center of Immunologic Prophylaxis, including the ban for burning sharps (needles etc) boxes. In this regard, WHO and the Republican Center of Immunologic Prophylaxis proposed to the SPA Preventive Medicine, to first test this standard in five (5) Feldsher Medical Stations and 5 Family Practice Cen

Disaggregated by age and ethnicity at last municipal elections: Age: 60% -18-30, 41.9%-31-40, 52% - 41-60; Ethnic groups: 60% -Kyrgyz ethnic group (migrants from other countries), 45.5% - Kyrgyz, 15.8% - other ethnic groups. Data on the second case (urban, Southern community): -87.8% participated at previous municipal (60.3%) and parliament (22.4%) elections. Disaggregated by age and ethnicity at last municipal elections: Age: 73.3% -18-30, 79.3%-31-40, 54.4% - 41-60, 50% - 61 and up. Whereas at parliament elections they are less active: Age: 20% -18-30, 17.2%-31-40, 28.1% - 41-60, 20% - 61 and up. Ethnic groups (municipal elections): 66.7% Kyrgyz, 51.7% - other ethnic groups; Ethnic groups (parliament elections): 22.2% Kyrgyz, 27.6% - other ethnic groups. 2) Baseline for Output Indicator 1.1.1: Data on the first case (Rural, Northern community): -80,2% of women exercised their electoral rights based on their own choice and will – independently. -Results were segregated by Age: 76% -18-30, 85.7%-31-40, 77.4%-41-60; Ethnicity: ethnic kyrgyz (migrants) - 75%, local Kyrgyz - 79.2%, other ethnic groups - 93.3%. Data on the second case (Urban, Southern community): -81.9% of women exercise their electoral rights independently. -Results were disaggregated by Age: 81.3% -18-30, 78.6%-31-40, 26.4%-41-60, 61 and up – 11.6%; Ethnicity: Kyrgyz – 86.9%, other ethnic groups - 75%. 3) Baseline for Outcome Indicator 2 a: Data on the first case (rural, northern community): - 13,6% of respondents have confirmed their ability and knowledge to promote democratic changes for the communities in peaceful manners Data on the second case (urban, southern community): - 28,2% of respondents have confirmed their ability and knowledge to promote democratic changes for the communities in peaceful manners 4) B

1) The project in total has engaged 16 local women’s and youth NGOs, who developed the national raising awareness interventions on women’s and youth's active participation in elections. Several knowledge management and advocacy materials were released for a wide-range of target audiences. Formal and informal meetings with the public were conducted, covering around 88,588 people. A TV series was released to create a positive image of women deputies and women on decision- making positions, the Central Election Committee was supported in releasing the Public Service Announcements(PSAs) that call women for active and self-paced participation in the Parliamentary elections, well-known TED Talks with prominent women-candidates and women-parliamentarians was organized in Osh/Bishkek, messages on active women's participation was spread covering all the country. An innovative tool in approaching women-candidates was used in a format of a board game that became popular among beneficiaries. 2) IP “Agency of Social Technologies” NGO has developed its’ own research methodology on Gender Rating of political parties. It is the system of public monitoring of political parties to evaluate the gender sensitivity for the certain period, based on four key measures. Public poll was conducted to reveal the level of gender credit of political parties. In order to wide-promote and discuss the results- media coverage, meetings and seminars as well as provision of the platform to initiate the discourse on the results of the gender rating system of political parties were put in place 3) Within this Outcome 5 Women's Leadership schools were organized to capacitate women from pilot areas to run for elections.They were engaged into understanding the general principles of women's empowerment as well as developing their election campaign. capital of a political entity

comment.narrative: 1. CEC faced new challenges due to massive introduction of ICT-tools into the citizens registration and identification announced by the Government and President’s appeal for voter registration. 2. Following the on-going electoral cycles the public confidence needs to be restored to meet the high ‘demand’ for democracy and credible participative elections.

The capacity and resource of Electoral Managment Bodies (EMB: CEC and SRS) strengthened to organize elections in conformity with national and international standards. The capacity and resource of EMBs strengthened in the area of communication to answer the high expectation for democracy and credibility and face the new challenge of the introduction of highly specialized electronic and identification equipment. Conduct of nationwide information and communication campaign on democratic elections, civic education, and the introduction of ICT. Creation of a peaceful and secure environment conducive to the organization of peaceful elections

The capacity and resource of Electoral Managment Bodies (EMB: CEC and SRS) strengthened to organize elections in conformity with national and international standards through the following activities: a country range trainings for 12,500 EMBs (CEC and SRS) specialists to work and maintain new electoral and identification equipment is done. The capacity and resource of EMBs strengthened in the area of communication through professional trainings provided for the press-services of CEC, SRS, Office of the Government and Security Service. An expert support provided for CEC to conduct and develop communication activities through out a year. Conducted of nationwide information and communication campaign on democratic elections, civic education, and the introduction of ICT through a country range voter education and public awaraness campaigns done by national non-governmental organizations supported by the Project. Created a peaceful and secure environment through organization of professional trainings for law-enforcement officers, prosecutors and judges. In total 500 official were trained through out a country in all regions.

comment.narrative: R1 1192 people, including 900 women from 24 target villages took part at Participatory Rural Assessment of needs of the village, directed to further improvement of their standard of living, in the formation of local development committees for the prioritization and coordination of project activities. R2 200 people, including 25 women were involved into the research process on improvement of effective pastures management. According to the results of research assistance on sustainable economic, environmental and social development of the industry will be provided. A reasonable balance between the needs of the rural population, wild and domestic animals, forestry, park facilities, the activities of which are reflected in the use of pastures will be kept. R3 120 residents, including 53 women from 6 villages were involved in the selection process of projects on installation of renewable energy and implementation of practices for sustainable use of resources and improved their capacity on operating and maintaining of installed equipment and in the introduction of the principles of "Green villages". R4 320 people, including 101 women had been involved into the business capacity assessment. Regulation of business center’s activity on the Oblast level and in Nookat rayon center was developed. R5 6 municipalities have been working on the creation of public service centers on the principle of "single window". In 17 municipalities strategic plans for sustainable development are worked out. R6 323 people, 113 women had access to information and knowledge on the use of alternative energy sources, pasture resourses management, improved quality of drinking water

R1 Local sustainable development plans and profiles of 16 municipalities have been developed through 39 different activities with the participation of 765 active residents, of which 284 are women. Local sustainable development plans for 16 municipalities are aimed at long-term vulnerability reduction of the population through the development of various economic activities, improving access to water, environmental safety, creating new jobs and restoring socio-economic infrastructure. They are developed on the basis of the Methodological Guidelines for the Development of Strategies and Plans for Sustainable Development of the Ministry of Economy of the KR (Order No. 107 dated July 4, 2014). R2 6686 pasture users, including 2,623 women, are informed of the implementation mechanisms of an electronic pasture management system. 3 municipalities use an electronic information system for pasture resources management. 686 people, including 211 women, received skills in using effective pasture management practices during 22 educational trainings. R3 Entrepreneurship Support Center (hereinafter referred as the Center) was created in Osh, where there was established 3 new jobs, including 1 for a woman. The Center has a legal status. It provides various consulting and information support for entrepreneurs. It was created with the joint support of state institutions, local business community and international agencies working in the sphere of development. Business process was organized in 4 municipalities on providing municipal services to the population including supporting entrepreneurs in simplifying procedures by implementing the principle of a "single window". More than 82 employees of these municipalities, including 28 women, received skills on good governance and development of public-private dialogue. The “green village” initiative was implemented in 5 communities, where 15 objects of business and social economic infrastructure were supported by the installation of the re

comment.narrative:
Output 1: An enabling environment for National Risk Assessment Framework created to apply innovative tools Baseline:
- National development concept on “Establishing National Information Management System on DRR” is in progress towards refining risk assessment & monitoring mechanisms - National Programme on Establishment Comprehensive System on Monitoring and Forecasting of Hazardous Natural Processes applying Geographical Information System (GIS) and Remote Sensing Techniques adopted and started to be implemented
Output 2: National Disaster Risk Monitoring and Early Warning systems as well as avalanche-risk reduction capacities strengthened alongside transport corridors Baseline: - Kyrgyzhydromet has avalanche-risk reduction unit with weak capacity and logistical infrastructure - Government approved the construction of two avalanche-monitoring stations in “Dolon” and “Chapchyma” mountain pass
Output 3: Resilience of vulnerable communities built and disaster prevention and response capacities strengthened Baseline: - National Programme on establishing the Unified Information Management System for Disaster and Crises Settings (UIMS) is in nprogress - Governmental Reform on re-profiling existing Firefighting Units into Fire-Rescuing Services is in progress
Output 4: Increased regional cooperation of Central Asian (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Turkmenistan) Disaster Management Authorities facilitated under the “Central Asia plus Japan” Dialogue

Output 1: An enabling environment for National Risk Assessment Framework created to apply innovative tools Targets for 2017: Technical assessments conducted by the experts from Japanese National Institutions In 2017, relevant desk review has been undertaken in order to identify possible experts from Japan specialized in GIS, Satellite and Risk Modelling Techniques. As of December 2017, there were identified 3 experts only, however, UNDP rules require 3 applicants per position, i.e. 9 experts in total. Additional consultations are still required to identify either additional 6 experts or apply a waiver.
Output 2: National Disaster Risk Monitoring and Early Warning systems as well as avalanche-risk reduction capacities strengthened alongside transport corridors Targets for 2017: Procurement planning, Sourcing of Suppliers, Solicitation & Evaluation Offers completed for purchase of avalanche-risk monitoring equipment and construction of two avalanche-monitoring stations As per the Programme goals, two avalanche-monitoring stations are planned in Jalal-Abad oblast (Chapchyma station) and Naryn oblast (Dolon station.). However, before launching respective actions, Kyrgyzhydromet officially noticed UNDP that it would like to change the place of construction of ‘Chapchyma’ meteo station to another station titled ‘Chatkal’ because of change of investment environment in Chatkal district. Namely, an alternative North-South Road is being planned by the Government and the gold mining companies such as ‘Chaarat Gold’ and ‘Chanach Gold’ operating in Chatkal district of Jalal-Abad oblast have already constructing a part of above-mentioned North-South Road to connect Chatkal and Alabuka districts. It therefore required agreements with Tokyo MFA through Embassy of Japan that took almost 2-3 months in order to change the place of construction. description.narrative: Transboundary Cooperation for Snow Leopard and Ecosystem Conservation
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to

This global project will strengthen transboundary conservation for snow leopards and their high mountain ecosystems to ensure stability of global snow leopard population.
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: The governments of the 12 range countries of the snow leopard (including Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan) have agreed through the Bishkek Declaration on the Conservation of Snow Leopards the need to conserve snow leopards and their critical high mountain ecosystems, and are investing in national efforts as a priority. Snow leopards are Endangered, suffering from wildlife crime, and degradation of their critical habitats by overgrazing and infrastructure development (mines, hydropower and tourism). Because their huge range spans many international borders, because of their great mobility, and because of international wildlife crime (both of snow leopards and their prey species), they can only be conserved with a high level of international cooperation in knowledge-sharing, monitoring, enforcement and land management.

description.narrative: Support the Unified State Population Registry to Establish the E-Governance System

E-Governmance project is aimed to provide technical support aimed at advancement of fully functioning Unified State Population Registry (USPR) in the Kyrgyz Republic, which will serve as a basis of e-Governance system in the Kyrgyz Republic.
independent political entity
Elections - elections

- Provide relevant equipment and technical support to SRS for further development of USPR, the issuance of new biometric passport and voter identification system; - Provide necessary trainings and training materials for SRS staff in order to operate new equipment.

comment.narrative: - Lack of equipment and technical support for further development of USPR, the issuance of new e-biometric passport (e-ID) and further improvement of voter identification system; - Poor capacity and technical skills of the SRS relevant staff to operate new equipment.

- Necessary equipment and technical support for further development of USPR, new biometric passport and voter identification system provided; - Trainings and training materials for capacity building and development of technical skills of SRS staff to operate new equipment conducted and provided.

All requested by SRS ICT delivered in due time, with no sufficient delay. The equipment will contribute the Unified State Population Register (USPR) to be its fully operational and containing actualized data, including data on biometrics, collected and inserted at sub-national and municipality’s level using ICTs.
